title: [New Splash Art] Lee Sin
body:
Here's the new upcoming splash art for Lee Sin:

http://i.imgur.com/oLaLZJh.jpg

I'll just paste here what I said in another forum:

"You can tell a straight dude did the new Lee Sin splash art because if a woman had been in that pose, we would see her ass in perfect definition, while Lee's is mysteriously obscured.

Where is my dude version of Frostblade Irelia, Riot. Where is it."

With Lee Sin's popularity I highly doubt you would've turned off potential players by giving him a more egalitarian splash art, so I consider this new splash art to be a colossal missed opportunity. I am rather disappointed.

What I'm trying to say is that instead of trying to sexualize men, the logical answer would be to de-sexualize women and instead make them fulfill their role/fantasy in their splash arts as well as in game. Can we have accidental sexy elements in both cases? yes please! and here is where I agree with you, a little more ass never hurt anyone but lets think a little bit:

-Hows Lee Sin in-game? well, he certainly have always had these pants so it's nothing new, they do conceal the little booty he has but to be honest you can still see some of it. Riot can't suddenly decide he's wearing spandex when he has a certain shape in-game.

So I think this explains why I understand the current low sexiness of this splash art. And of course there's the face, a HUGE change from current lee sin ({{champion:64}} for reference) who happened to be a man with Chinese features, small nose, small lips, some facial hair, square-ish chin and rugged but not stupidly manly head, all in all great features that happen to feel somewhat Chinese (let's be real they have very specific ways when it comes to manliness) pretty much like what Yasuo has going for him, though in a different way. Well, if you want to get down to the nitty-gritty of it, shirtlessness on a dude is at once sexy and not sexy. It's not sexy when presented alone and unadorned, but shirtlessness CAN be made sexy under the right conditions (right pose, right lighting, maybe throw in some water dripping down the muscles). The V-shaped muscles on a dude's hips are definitely sexy and it'd be awesome to have more of that (I think Varus and maybe Brand have a little bit of that going on).

Well, Pantheon is a great example of a dead-serious dude who can dress as skimpy as he wants and you will still respect him, given that his mechanics are beast, his voice acting is excellent and his overall look is rather fearsome. Similarly, you can probably put Tryndamere in a tiny loincloth and he would still be scary as hell, given that he's a rage-fueled barbarian that will dive you under tower, kill you and then walk out.

My beef with Zyra is that if she's a plant possessing a human, she can either be like "clothes? what are clothes?" and just cover herself entirely in bark/leaves (since she is, you know, a plant, and plants are very keen on protecting their soft, vulnerable interiors), or she can go "yes, humans do this thing called clothing" and *dress properly* (The way that Brand, an elemental entity of fire, kept pants on the guy he possessed). What she does is this half-way thing that makes no sense whatsoever. Also, according to Elise's backstory, she is the leader of a cult, which means her way to lure people is more related to her voice and charisma than her looks. This same beef I have with LeBlanc. She's a powerful assassin-mage, the timeless leader of a secret society. Why is she dressed like a stripper.

Ahri is the only one that fits, yes, and I'm miffed we don't have a charm-based male champion to balance the scales. Would it be *that* hard to just pull a random Noxian and make him basically like pre-transformation Cassiopea? Some hot dude that ferrets out secrets and manipulates people with his looks and charm, it can't be that hard to come up with a kit based on that (especially since the Charmed condition is pretty much unused).

Also sorry I gave the wrong impression, but I'm a dude as well. I consider myself bi, though I lean heavily towards guys (which is why this topic interests me so!). It's honestly not that hard to make tasteful sexy dudes. It's really, really not. Some people like to blow it out proportion in order to have an easy excuse not to do it, but it really all basically boils down to "use the same thought processes you use on the women, but on the men instead". I will say that Evelynn is rather tasteless even for her character concept, but if you take Ahri instead, you can see that effort was made into keeping her alluring but still tasteful.

You can easily make pre-existing character sexier by just making small adjustments. Put Tryndamere in a fur loincloth. Cut some windows in Pantheon's chestplate to show off his muscles. Remove that thing Varus has across his chest. Remove the leather that Draven has under the V-neck and let his abs shine. Give Aatrox some clothes around his waist (loincloth, codpiece, torn pants, whatever) so that he's not a sexless creature. Make Yasuo's half-cloak thing smaller so that we can actually see more of his chest.

Basically, the key is to A) show more skin, B) make that skin alluring. A is super easy to do and requires no explanation, but B is all about how you frame that skin that's showing. If female characters have to endure useless armour that offers little to no protection (like Irelia's chestplate, which leaves her upper chest completely exposed), so should dudes. Some dudes should have sensible armour, like Leona and Diana do, but there should definitely be dudes with horribly impractical armour to balance out the scales.

For example, this is a fanmade skin for Garen:

http://fc07.deviantart.net/fs70/f/2013/178/3/4/league_of_legends_garen_skin_texture_adonis_by_haruhi81-d6axo7s.png

Sorry for the wall of text.

Wait, what? You are complaining that this depiction of a half-naked Lee Sin with rippling muscles that are so detailed as to have the veins outlined in them, is not enough? Wot. 

Maybe the splash art should just have him striking down those parrying totems in a thong. {{champion:84}}

While I wouldn't complain at all if we got Lee Sin in a thong, I think that if you look at the picture clearly, you can see that deliberate steps were taken to make it as unsexy as possible:

* The character is bare-chested, yet the angle of the image is from below, which means that his (clothed) lower body obscures part of his upper body. 
* Furthermore, the action pose has his torso curving back, so that in the end, all we can see from his chest is one pec and 3-4 abs. Now what we can see IS pretty, but the pose and the image angle make it so that his main asset (shirtlessness) is as obscured as possible.
* In case anybody likes the sight of strong bare arms, his right arm is almost completely covered by his body, and his left arm is obscured by shadows (which stems from image angle and the position of the image's light source, both of which are decisions made by the artist).
* His pants are designed to be as unsexy as possible. Not only are they loose and conceal any muscles or curves his legs/ass may have, they are also of a dark, solid colour that helps shadows obscure his form.
* As I mentioned before, there is a deliberate choice to shadow his ass as much as possible.
* Lee Sin's only selling point in this image, other than the 1/4 of chest we can see, is his face, and Lee Sin in particular cannot rely on his face to sell a picture, given that his blindfold is enormous and easily covers half his face, he doesn't have a very pleasant hairstyle, and his mouth/jaw/cheeks are rather generic. I could let the hairstyle and the generic jaw/cheeks/mouth slide, but eyes and facial expression are hugely important if you want a person to sell attractiveness based on his face. Thanks to the blindfold, this is impossible for Lee Sin.

In short, this depiction of Lee Sin seems to take whatever might make him attractive and deliberately obscure/conceal it as much as possible.

EDIT: My last point about Lee Sin's face is not that anything about his face should be changed, but that the artist shouldn't rely on Lee Sin's face to be his main source of attractiveness.

If they are able to exercise such freedom of decisions as actually deciding to angle him away from the viewer, then you have a point. 

Another way to look at it, though, is that good art leaves some things to the imagination. Cheers.

I'm pretty sure artists are given a significant degree of artistic liberty at Riot, within some general guidelines, which means I can hold the artist accountable for things like angle, light source and shadowing (which aren't subjective, btw. The decision of where the light source in the picture is located, is an objective fact that can be readily seen by anybody looking at the picture, same with the angle and shadowing).

As for the last part... if that was the case, Riot could simply clothe every female champion from head to toe in heavy robes and body armour and say that it's leaving things to the imagination. But they don't. So it'd be nice to have some equality in that department. :)
I disagree with you on the face. To me, it's the worst part of the whole splash art and the first thing that needs to be changed. And this is coming from someone who appreciates attractive men.

Yeah, that was my point. "His only selling point is his face because you've obscured the rest of his body." And I then go on to detail why making a splash art that focuses on the face is especially bad when it comes to Lee Sin.

Basically I was criticising the idea of obscuring his body and focusing on the face of a character that conceals a third of his face. And then they bungle up the face anyway.

Acolyte Lee Sin's face is even more obscured, but I think the parts you do see are very attractive. 

http://img2.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20110401110852/leagueoflegends/images/7/7e/Lee_Sin_AcolyteLoading.jpg

Lee Sin's new face isn't bad because it's obscured; it's just plain bad. Actually, the best part of his head in the new art is the *blindfold*. The mouth, nose, cheeks, jaw and neck (in the thumbnail*), basically all the parts that you can see, are what ruin the whole picture.

*Ha! Thumbnail. Because he looks like a thumb!

I do agree that the new facial features are rather "generic square-jawed, thick-necked action hero" and fail to measure up to his previous form.

The nose, mouth, and chin are all I need to see in order to get a general idea of what the rest of his face looks like. The hood adds a sense of mystery, which a lot of people find sexy. I actually think Acolyte Lee Sin is the sexiest skin in the whole game. I don't need a bare chest or form fitting pants to see that he has a great body.

You're saying Lee Sin cannot have an attractive face simply because he is wearing a blindfold. On that point, you're right, we cannot agree.

Well, I'm not gonna knock you for being able to imagine sexiness based on the barest of hints.

Unfortunately, not everyone is the same. I consider Traditional Lee Sin to be the sexiest Lee Sin skin and it's mostly the hair that does it for me, while the sexiest skin in the entire game (for me) is probably Ruthless Pantheon. As you can see, we have rather different tastes. And that's okay!

The reason why the blindfold is such a sore spot is because eyes, cheekbones and eyebrows are important for a lot of people in order to determine whether a face is attractive or not, and they are also vital in conveying facial expressions. Even if it's not an obstacle for you, it is for a significant amount (and I would say the majority) of people.

I do see the complaints here, but I think you are attaching a cause to the effect that just isn't there. Riot isn't purposely doing this, it's honestly them just putting it into a pose they like and it just happens to hide things. They are big advocates of "art style" and this art style generally is very dark and realistic these days. 

I would say with new splash arts they are going to be much more hit or miss on sexiness. because sexy splash arts are going to be more for characters who it makes sense for, rather than just all of them.

you can argue with me about it all day, but the new vayne splash art half of her body is obscured just as well, the new shyvana splash art, you aren't looking at her curves, you are looking at the giant mountain sized epic armor she is wearing. if they did a new splash art for ahri it would probably be as sexual as possible because it makes sense for the character, and if they did one for jarvan or jayce it probably would be as well (those are definately 2  characters I think are pretty well known for their attractiveness)

so yeah I agree they could have done a better job, and yes there is slight bias because most of the artists are probably guys, but this splash art looks gritty and realistic, the vayne one also looks  dark and unless you like contorted pretzel girls isn't that overly sexy, and the shyvana one is just giant metal armor honestly. but you definately can't deny progress, I just don't think you should be saying riot did this one purpose, because they talk ALL the time about how they are trying better to make both sexes represented, so I think they at least deserve props for trying more than most game developers

When everything points in the same direction, I find it hard to dismiss it as a coincidence.

Well, I certainly wouldn't have minded if they went in a sexier direction with Lee Sin, I'm more upset that they made him quite ugly. He was a good looking guy before (and still is attractive in all of his skins). Now his icon is just unpleasant to look at.

I also notice, when you put the two icons next to each other, that they seem to have white-washed Lee Sin. I hadn't realised his skin tone was actually Chinese-looking in the previous splash art.

Also not sure where you're going with the complaints regarding sexualization. The last splash updated with a groundhog's view was Sona's, AFAIK. I guess you complained about her lack of sexualization then, also?
Why would I complain? It's not like there isn't plenty of cleavage and girl-butt to go around.
the debonair and pool party boys don't do it for you?

I like the proposed fixes people have put forth here. As it is, I'm not really a big fan of the new art. His face just looks too off.
